descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: What can shopping teach us about history? Something we do almost every day, shopping has a history that is tied up with the development of capitalism, empire and globalization, new roles for women and ideas about the family, changes in political culture, and new ideas about the self. In this research seminar, we will ask how such a mundane activity came to be laden with such varied and often negative meanings. How have people's relationships to the goods they purchase changed from the industrial revolution to the present? How have writers, philosophers, physicians, and critics conceived of the act of shopping? How have people thought about class, gender, race, nation, and politics through consumption? Can consumption be a political act? Drawing on primary sources (historical and literary texts), feminist scholarship, and historical monographs, this class with grapple with the historical relationships between consumption, sexuality, gender, race, and politics on a global scale.
